bibl.title: Letter from R.H. Creek to Henry Rose Carter, December 24, 1924

div1.p: Creek writes that he has never encountered an epidemic of plague on board ship.

div1.head: Letter from R.H. Creek to Henry Rose Carter, December 24, 1924
div1.opener:
Book (Put will be Peste
PPeste
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
SAN FRANCISCO QUARANTINE STATION
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
ANGEL ISLAND, CALIF.
December 24, 1924
Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter,
2122 California Street, N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
I owe you an apology for not sooner answering
your inquiry of November 29th. The letter, however,
was delivered to Dr. Perry's office in San Francisco
and Dr. Wayson handed it to me as we were boarding a
train for Los Angeles. I put it in my overcoat poc-
ket and only yesterday did it recur to my mind. I
have never known of any outbreak of plague aboard ves-
sels on the high seas, either bubonic or pnuemonic
that might have been termed an epidemic. While I have
personal knowledge of several infected ships on which
there were human cases aboard, I do not recall any that
had more than one human case.

I planned to run out and see you whilst I was in
Washington, but somehow or other my time was so occupied
that I had to leave before seeing many of my friends.
